title: There are several more detailed and longer histories of chemistry
The Norton History of Chemistry
A History of Chemistry
A History of Chemistry,  vols
1 First Steps: From Alchemy to Chemistry? Three books offer both a general discussion of the history of alchemy and a detailed study of the alchemy of Robert Boyle
The Aspiring Adept: Robert Boyle and His Alchemical Quest
Gehennical Fire: The Lives of George Starkey, an American Alchemist in the Scientific Revolution
The Janus Faces of Genius: The Role of Alchemy in Newton’s Thought
The Norton History of Chemistry, discusses the modern achievement of transmutation

container-title: Instruments and Experimentation in the History of Chemistry
A Scientific Autobiography of Joseph Priestley (
note: . Joseph Black, Experiments upon Magnesia Alba (), has been reprinted as Alembic Club Reprint, No. 

Scribner’s: New York, ); a good recent biography is Jean-Pierre Poirier, Lavoisier: Chemist, Biologist, Economist (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, ). Two excellent detailed studies of Lavoisier’s laboratory practice are F. L. Holmes, Lavoisier and the Chemistry of Life: An Exploration of Scientific Creativity (Madison: University of Wisconsin Press, ), and, by the same author, Antoine Lavoisier—The Next Crucial Year: Or, The Sources of His Quantitative Method in Chemistry (Princeton: Princeton University Press, ). Lavoisier’s book, Elements of Chemistry, trans. R. Kerr (Edinburgh, ; actually published in ), has been reprinted (New York: Dover, ).
title: Historical Studies in the Language of Chemistry

The most complete history of chemical affinity (not yet translated into English) is Michelle Goupil, Du flou au clair? Histoire de l’affinité chimique de Cardan à Prigogine (Paris: Comité des Travaux Historiques et Scientifiques, ). For Scottish chemistry and its context
Philosophical Chemistry in the Scottish Enlightenment: The Doctrines and Discoveries of William Cullen and Joseph Black
The Chemical Revolution
5 Different Kinds of Air An excellent introductory essay to eighteenth-century chemistry and the chemical revolution is Maurice P
Chemistry and the Chemical Revolution
The Ferment of Knowledge: Studies in the Historiography of Eighteenth-Century Science
Crosland discusses early instruments for the handling of gases in chap
which I have drawn on freely. Levere discusses eudiometry, the measurement of the goodness of gases, in chap.  of the same book, and Holmes discusses Lavoisier’s research apparatus in chap
Joseph Priestley appears engagingly in Robert E
Schofield has also written a fine account of Priestley’s first forty years, The Enlightenment of Joseph Priestley: A Study of His Life and Work from
The literature on Lavoisier and the chemical revolution is enormous. The best introduction remains Henry Guerlac, Antoine-Laurent Lavoisier

note: ; reprint, Yverdon and Langhorne: Gordon and Breach, ). The methodological debates are explored in John Hedley Brooke, Thinking About Matter: Studies in the History of Chemical Philosophy (Aldershot, Hampshire, and Brookfield, Vt.: Variorum, ). Liebig and Wöhler’s paper on the benzoyl radical can be read in translation in O. T. Benfey, Classics in the Theory of Chemical Combination (New York: Dover, ), along with key writings by Laurent and Gerhardt.
title: Eighteenth-Century Chemistry as an Investigative Enterprise (Berkeley: Office for the History of Science and Technology, University of California, ), has an excellent chapter on eighteenth-century vegetable chemistry. For Lavoisier’s research in organic chemistry, see the same author’s Lavoisier and the Chemistry of Life: An Exploration of Scientific Creativity
The background to the arguments in this chapter is explored in T
Affinity and Matter: Elements of Chemical Philosophy

note: 11 Atoms in Space For Frankland, see C. A. Russell, Edward Frankland: Chemistry, Controversy and Conspiracy in Victorian England (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, ). Several of the key papers discussed in this chapter are reprinted in translation in O. T. Benfey, Classics in the Theory of Chemical Combination (New York: Dover, ). The best translation of Van’t Hoff ’s paper is in Peter J. Ramberg and Geert J. Somsen, “The Young J. H. van’t Hoff: The Background to the Publication of His  Pamphlet on the Tetrahedral Carbon Atom, Together with a New English Translation,” Annals of Science  (): –.

title: New Frontiers For a guide to the new artificial elements, consult Albert Stwertka, A Guide to the Elements
For the new physical chemistry
The World of Physical Chemistry
The Most Beautiful Molecule: The Discovery of the Buckyball
For an account of a variety of fascinating molecules, see Philip Ball, Designing the Molecular World: Chemistry at the Frontier
For the discovery of DNA, there are accounts in two very different styles: James D. Watson, The Double Helix: A Personal Account of the Discovery of the Structure of DNA
The Path to the Double Helix
For relatively modern biochemistry, see Steven Rose with Sarah Bullock, The Chemistry of Life
There is much about the role of chemistry in relation to biology in John Maddox
For the history of genetic engineering, see Susan Aldridge, The Thread of Life: The Story of Genes and Genetic Engineering
